Knowledge Point: \isi{Coordinating conjunctions} are a (before consonant) / ad (before vowel) `and' (\ref{ex:coord1}), api `and, and then' (\ref{ex:coord1}), u tga ... né tga `either ... or' (\ref{ex:coord6}), né tga `or', pi `then' (\ref{ex:coord2}), ábar `but' (\ref{ex:coord3}), and dantaun `however, but' (\ref{ex:coord4}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll \textbf{U} \textbf{tga} té fas ùrdan ajn tia tgombra \textbf{né} \textbf{tga} té lavas gjù. | \gls either COMP 2SG do.PRS.2SG order.M.SG in POSS.2SG.F.SG room or COMP 2SG wash.PRS.2SG down | \glt`Either you tidy up your room or you do the dishes.'
Content 4: \gll Mintgataun mavan nuṣ èra … plas pitgògnas a cavá cristalas anstagl mirá dlas tgauras, \textbf{pi} vignévan nus halt in téc tart. | \gls sometimes go.IMPF.1PL 1PL also … through.DEF.F.PL steep_slope.PL SUBORD dig.INF crystal.F.PL instead look_for.INF of.DEF.F.PL goat.PL and come.IMPF.1PL 1PL simply INDEF.M.SG bit late | \glt `From time to time we would also … go farther up to extract crystals instead of looking after the goats, and then we would come back a bit late.'
Content 6: \gll Basta, da fá fùssi ùssa gl atún la pjal plajna da tùtas uísas. \textbf{Dantaun} scha l' aura tégn ansjaman vòi schòn. | \gls enough COMP do.INF be.COND.3SG.EXPL now DEF.M.SG autumn DEF.F.SG skin full of all.F.PL way.PL however if DEF.F.SG weather hold.PRS.3SG together go.PRS.3SG.EXPL indeed | \glt `Well, now during autumn there would be a lot of things to do. However, if the weather holds, it will do indeed.'

Knowledge Point: In the case of coordination with né `or', the complementiser tga must be used with clauses as in (\ref{ex:coord5}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Subject clauses are either finite or non-finite. If the \isi{non-finite subject clause} is located at the beginning of the sentence, the \isi{infinitive} may be modified by the definite masculine \isi{article} (\ref{ex:subjclause1} and \ref{ex:subjclause2}) or may lack it (\ref{ex:subjclause3} and \ref{ex:subjclause4}), without any functional change.
Content 1: \gll Òh \textbf{gl} \textbf{ampréndar} \textbf{tudèstg} è stau, l’ antschata ṣè quaj schòn stau in téc curjù̱s. | \gls oh DEF.M.SG learn.INF German.M.SG be.PRS.3SG COP.PTCP.UNM DEF.F.SG beginning be.PRS.3SG DEM.UNM indeed COP.PTCP.UNM INDEF.M.SG bit strange.ADJ.UNM | \glt `Oh, to learn German was, at the beginning this was indeed a little bit strange.'
Content 2: \gll [...] ábar \textbf{al} \textbf{trá} \textbf{ajn} \textbf{èla} èra … da maz. | \gls … but DEF.M.SG pull.INF in 3SG.F COP.IMPF.3SG … of killing.M.SG | \glt `[...] but bringing it in was ... terrible.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Fugí} è bian, a \textbf{mitschè} è aun mé̱gljar. | \gls flee.INF COP.PRS.3SG good and escape.INF COP.PRS.3SG still better | \glt `To flee is good, and to escape is even better.'
Content 4: \gll A \textbf{dumagnè} als amprèmṣ dis quèls pòrs gjù da da quaj trùtg ajnagjù a sjantar atrás l’ aua dal Drun tga vagnéva mù pauc vi da tschèla vart, \textbf{qu}’ è stau álṣò in martéri. | \gls and cope.INF DEF.M.SG first.PL day.PL DEM.M.PL pig.PL down from from DEM.M.SG path into_and_down and after through DEF.F.SG water of.DEF.M.SG PN REL come.IMPF.3SG only little over of DEM.F.SG side DEM.UNM. be.PRS.3SG COP.PTCP.UNM well INDEF.M.SG ordeal | \glt `And the first days, to cope with these pigs [going] down this path and then through the water of the Drun, of which only few would go over to the other side, well, this was an ordeal [...].'

Knowledge Point: It is also possible to use the complementiser da (\ref{ex:subjclause7}), but in this case the \isi{infinitive} is highlighted.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Da} \textbf{còschar} fùs stau mé̱gljar. | \gls COMP keep_silent.INF be.COND.3SG COP.PTCP.UNM better | \glt `To keep silent would have been better.'

Knowledge Point: If the \isi{subject clause} is located after the verb, the \isi{expletive pronoun} i is required in subject position and the \isi{infinitive} may be introduced by the complementiser da (\ref{ex:subjclause5}) or may lack it (\ref{ex:subjclause6}).
Content 1: \gll I è stau mé̱gljar \textbf{da} \textbf{còschar}. | \gls EXPL be.PRS.3SG COP.PTCP.UNM better COMP keep_silent.INF | \glt `It was better to keep silent.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \isi{Finite subject clauses} are introduced by the complementiser tga; the \isi{expletive} \isi{pronoun} i must occur in subject position (\ref{ex:subjclause8} and \ref{ex:subjclaus10}).
Content 1: \gll Ad \textbf{i} è aun schabagjau plé … \textbf{tga} nuṣ èssan i … tiar duas, álṣò ajn duaṣ jèdas … tiar ina api sjantar aun í ad í vi tiar tschèla. | \gls and EXPL be.PRS.3SG in_addition happen.PTCP.UNM more … COMP 1PL be.PRS.1PL go.PTCP.M.PL … to two.F.PL well in two.F time.PL … to one.F.SG and afterwars in_addition go.PTCP.M.PL and go.PTCP.M.PL over to DEM.F.SG | \glt `And it also happened more … that we went … to two [girls], well at two different moments … to the one and went also, and went over to the other.'
Content 2: \gll Ad \textbf{i} èr’ è bitga úsit \textbf{tg}’ ins \textbf{mava} \textbf{a} \textbf{scùlèta}. | \gls and EXPL COP.IMPF.3SG also NEG usage.M.SG COMP GNR go.IMPF.3SG to nursery_school.F.SG | \glt `And it was not usual that one attended nursery school.'

Knowledge Point: Object clauses can be finite or non-finite.\isi{Non-finite object clauses} are introduced by the complementiser da (\ref{ex:objcl1} and \ref{ex:objcl2}).
Content 1: \gll Al pástar gròn ò \textbf{atmonju} \textbf{da} bétga \textbf{fá} tupadats. | \gls DEF.M.SG herdsman big have.PRS.3SG admonish.PTCP.UNM COMP NEG do.INF stupidity.F.PL | \glt `The main herdsman warned [people] not to commit stupidities.'
Content 2: \gll [...] api vagi èl \textbf{tartgau} ... \textbf{dad} \textbf{í} \textbf{vi} ajn via ... a tanaj sé èls. | \gls … and have.PRS.SBJV.3SG 3SG.M think.PTCP.UNM … COMP go.INF over on road.F.SG … and hold.INF up 3PL.M | \glt `[...] and he thought... that he would go on the road ... and stop them.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Finite object clauses} are introduced by the complementiser tga `that' (\ref{ex:objcl13}) or scha `whether' (\ref{ex:objcscha1}). Tga is not always adjacent to the main verb; in (\ref{ex:sacutga}) a preposed \isi{temporal clause} belonging to the \isi{object clause} separates the complementiser from the main verb, savaj in this case.
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll [...] a … lu vajn nuṣ, va ju dumandau \textbf{sch}’ èl prandèssi mè tòcan … a Ruèras. | \gls … and … then have.PRS.1PL 1PL have.PRS.1SG 1SG ask.PTCP.UNM if 3SG.M take.COND.INDIR.3SG 1SG until … to PN | \glt `[...] and … then we, I asked whether he could take me down to Rueras.'
Content 3: \gll Ju \textbf{sa} cu [...] ju sùn maridaus \textbf{tga} … èri ajn Camischùlas circa quindiṣch ufauns … tga mavan a scùla da Camischùlas. | \gls 1SG know.PRS.1SG when … 1SG be.PRS.1SG marry.PTCP.M.SG COMP … EXIST.IMPF.3SG.EXPL in PN about fifteen child.M.PL … REL go.IMPF.3PL to school.F.SG of PN | \glt `I know that when when … when I got married … there were in Camischolas about fifteen … children who attended the school of Camischolas.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Indirect interrogative clauses}, which are a subcategory of \isi{object clauses}, are either finite (\ref{ex:indinterr1}--\ref{ex:indinterr8}) or non-finite (\ref{ex:indinterr9}). They do not trigger \isi{subject inversion}, in contrast to direct interrogative sentences (see \sectref{sec:5.2}). An exception occurs in (\ref{ex:indinterr9}), where the \isi{non-finite interrogative clause} is focused on and precedes the verb, which triggers \isi{subject inversion}.
Content 1: \gll [...] a \textbf{damònda} \textbf{cù} i vòndi. | \gls … and ask.PRS.3SG how EXPL go.PRS.SBJV.3SG | \glt `[…] and he asked how he was.'
Content 2: \gll [...] a lu ò `l \textbf{grju} li gljut [...] tga ségi trajs rùsnas; ajn \textbf{tgénina} èl dégi métar ajn la crusch. | \gls … and then have.PRS.3SG 3SG.M shout.PTCP.UNM DEF.DAT.SG people.F.SG … COMP EXIST.PRS.SBJV.3SG.EXPL three hole.F.PL into which.F.SG 3SG.M must.PRS.SBJV.3SG put into DEF.F.SG cross | \glt `[...] and then he shouted to the people [...] [saying that] there were three holes; [asking] into which he should put the cross.'

Knowledge Point: A special case is (\ref{ex:indinterr10}) in which the \isi{manner clause} introduced by scù `like, as' modifies the manner adverb usché `so'.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \isi{Prepositional argument clauses} are non-finite. In the corpus, the following verbs occur: amprèndar d'ancanùschar `get to know' (\ref{ex:preparg1}), antschajvar a `begin to' (\ref{ex:preparg2}), calá da `stop doing' (\ref{ex:preparg3}), prèndar avaun da `plan' (\ref{ex:preparg4}), and sadacídar da `decide to' (\ref{ex:preparg5}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Sé Nalps vèvani è grad \textbf{antschiat} \textbf{a} bagagè cantinaṣ ètcè̱tara. | \gls up PN have.IMPF.3PL.3PL also just start.PTCP.UNM COMP build.INF canteen.F.PL et_cetera | \glt `In Nalps they had just begun to build canteens and so on.'
Content 3: \gll Ju \textbf{cala} \textbf{dad} \textbf{í} a scùlèta, ju pùs bitg' í plé. | \gls 1SG stop.PRS.1SG COMP go.INF to nursery_school.F.SG 1SG can.PRS.1SG NEG go.INF any_more | \glt `I’ll stop going to nursery school, I can’t stand it any longer.'

Knowledge Point: Temporal clauses are either finite or non-finite. \isi{Non-finite temporal clauses} are introduced by da (\ref{ex:tempcltgu1} -- \ref{ex:nonfintempcl4}), avaun ca (\ref{ex:nonfintempcl3}), or sjantar (\ref{ex:sjantarnonf1}).
Content 1: \gll […] faː ajn […] ʦaˈkɔnʣ diants aʎ rǝʃˈtiː dɐ lɐ ˈdʊːnɐ ʨɐ l ɔ rut ɔːr ejr \textbf{dɐ} \textbf{mɐˈʦaː} in ruʃp | \gls … make.INF in … some.M.PL tooth.PL DAT rake.M.SG of DEF.F.SG woman REL 3SG.M have.PRS.3SG break.PTCP.UNM out also SUBORD kill.INF INDEF.M.SG toad | \glt `[…] put in some teeth to the woman’s rake he had broken when he killed a toad.'
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{da} \textbf{gjantá} … sch’ ina sòra … tudèstga èra … vida majṣa, scha stuèvan tùt quèla- nuṣ ròmòntschas raṣdá tudèstg. | \gls and SUBORD lunch.INF … if INDEF.F.SG nun … German COP.IMPF.3SG … at_of table.F.SG CORR must.IMPF.3PL all DEM.F.SG 1PL Romansh.F.PL speak.INF German.M.SG | \glt `And during lunch … if a German … nun was … at table, all these – we, the Romansh speaking people, had to speak German.'
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Sjantar} \textbf{vaj} \textbf{fatg} als pènṣumṣ, ṣ' als scùlarṣ i a spaz. | \gls after have.INF do.PTCP.UNM DEF.ART.M.PL homework.PL be.PRS.3SG DEF.ART.M.PL pupil.PL go.PTCP.M.PL to walk | \glt `After doing their homework, the pupils went for a walk.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Finite temporal clauses} are introduced by avaun ca tga `before', cu `when', dafartáuntiar tga `whilst', durònt tga `when', schi glajti scù `as soon as', sjantar tga `after' (\ref{ex:sjantarf1}), and tòca `until'.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Sjantar} \textbf{tga} nuṣ vajn vju al film, èssan nuṣ i a durmí. | \gls after SUBORD 1PL have.PRS.1PL see.PTCP.M.PL DEF.ART.M.SG film be.PRS.1PL 1PL go.PTCP.UNM SUBORD sleep.INF | \glt `After we saw the film, we went to sleep.'

Knowledge Point: With the subordinator cu (derived from the interrogative pronoun cura `when'), correlative scha `if, then' is usually used (\ref{ex:cuscha1} and \ref{ex:cuscha2}).
Content 1: \gll […] \textbf{cu} i dat la banadiczjun, \textbf{scha} fò la sòntga crusch. | \gls … when EXPL give.PRS.3SG DEF.F.SG blessing CORR make.IMP.2SG DEF.F.SG holy cross | \glt `[…] when it comes to the blessing, make the sign of the cross.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Instead of cu `when' one also finds tga, which in combination with ju `I' is realised as tgu (\ref{ex:tempcltgu2} and\ref{ex:tempcltgu3}).
Content 1: \gll A sjantar [...] ṣè `l bap lu mòrts \textbf{tgu} vèva … mù vèntgadúṣ òns. | \gls and after … be.PRS.3SG DEF.M.SG father then die.PTCP.M.SG SUBORD.1SG have.IMPF.3SG … only twenty-two year.M.PL | \glt `And after that [...] my father then died when I was … only 22 years old.'

Knowledge Point: Non-finite manner clauses are introduced by cun `with' (\ref{ex:manncl1}) and finite manner clauses either by scù (\ref{ex:manncl2}), scù tga (\ref{ex:manncl3}), or only tga (\ref{ex:manncl4}).
Content 1: \gll Gè, i fùs schòn flòt, ábar ju sùn è vagnúṣ atrás \textbf{cun} \textbf{fá} `\textbf{l} \textbf{pur}. | \gls yes EXPL COP.COND.3SG really great.ADJ.UNM but 1SG be.PRS.1SG also come.PTCP.M.SG through with do.INF DEF.M.SG farmer | \glt `Yes, this would be really great, but I also could earn a living by being a farmer.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Non-finite purposive clauses} are introduced by a after a \isi{verb of movement} (\ref{ex:purp:inf:1} and \ref{ex:purp:inf:2}) and by par/pr̩ (\ref{ex:purp:inf:3}) or da (\ref{ex:purp:inf:4} and \ref{ex:purp:inf:5}) in all other cases; da, however, is very rare. Example (\ref{ex:purp:inf:2}) contains both par and a.

Knowledge Point: \isi{Finite purposive clauses} are introduced by par par tga (\ref{ex:purppartga}) or only by tga (\ref{ex:purptga}).
Content 1: \gll A la sèra \textbf{par} \textbf{tga} \textbf{briṣchi} bétg … vagnéva quaj, quaj mava `l ajnagjù cul maun èra sènza … [vòns] a trèva vidò̱ còtgla gjù sé sél plantschju. | \gls and DEF.F.SG evening SUBORD COMP burn.PRS.SBJV.3SG NEG … PASS.AUX.IMPF.3SG DEM.UNM DEM.UNM go.IMPF.3SG 3SG.M in_down with.DEF.M.SG hand also without … [glove.M.PL] and pull.IMPF.3SG out charcoal.COLL down up on.DEF.M.SG floor | \glt `And in the evening, to avoid it burning … was that, there he went into [the fire] with one hand, also without [gloves], and pulled out charcoal from down there up to the floor.'
Content 2: \gll A quaj stèvnṣ èssar … pulits-pulits l’ jamna … {\longrule} \textbf{tg}’ al bap \textbf{dètschi} in frang a miaz. | \gls and DEM.UNM must.IMPF.1PL.1PL COP.INF … RED\textasciitilde{well_behaved}.M.PL DEF.F.SG week … … COMP DEF.M.SG father give.PRS.SBJV.3SG one.M.SG franc and half.M.SG | \glt `And we had to be … very well-behaved during the week … so that my father would give [us] one and a half francs.'

Knowledge Point: In the DRG materials, there is one occurrence of the negator bétg preceding the subordinator tga, i.e. outside the subordinate clause (\ref{ex:betgtga1}).
Content 1: \gll Vèndardé sògn stù in muantá la tgarn a las ljòngjas \textbf{bétga} \textbf{tga} vignan ajn als baus. | \gls Friday.M.SG holy must.PRS.3SG GNR move.INF DEF.F.SG meat and DEF.F.PL sausage.PL NEG SUBORD come.PRS.3PL in DEF.M.PL beetle.PL | \glt `On Good Friday one must move the meat and the sausages so that the beetles cannot get into the meat.'

Knowledge Point: This construction has not been accepted by my consultants; however, a similar construction which, in contrast to the Tuatschin example (\ref{ex:betgtga1}), includes the subordinator par, can be found in other Romansh varieties like in the \ili{Sutsilvan} dialect of Dalin (\ref{ex:betgtga2}).
Content 1: \gll Vèndardé sògn stù in muantá la tgarn a las ljòngjas \textbf{bétga} \textbf{tga} vignan ajn als baus. | \gls Friday.M.SG holy must.PRS.3SG GNR move.INF DEF.F.SG meat and DEF.F.PL sausage.PL NEG SUBORD come.PRS.3PL in DEF.M.PL beetle.PL | \glt `On Good Friday one must move the meat and the sausages so that the beetles cannot get into the meat.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Par} \textbf{bétg} \textbf{tg}' in schleschi dat il calger eign in pêr guspas els calzers. | \gls for NEG SUBORD GNR slip.PRS.SBJV.3SG give.PRS.3SG DEF.M.SG shoemaker in INDEF.M.SG couple nail.PL in.DEF.M.PL shoe.PL | \glt `In order not to slip, the shoemaker hits some nails into the shoes.'

Knowledge Point: Therefore it is possible that the Tuatschin construction in (\ref{ex:betgtga1}) belonged to an older variety of the language.
Content 1: \gll Vèndardé sògn stù in muantá la tgarn a las ljòngjas \textbf{bétga} \textbf{tga} vignan ajn als baus. | \gls Friday.M.SG holy must.PRS.3SG GNR move.INF DEF.F.SG meat and DEF.F.PL sausage.PL NEG SUBORD come.PRS.3PL in DEF.M.PL beetle.PL | \glt `On Good Friday one must move the meat and the sausages so that the beetles cannot get into the meat.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Non-finite causal clauses} are introduced by da (\ref{ex:caus1}), and \isi{finite causal clauses} are introduced by parquaj/pr̩quaj tga (\ref{ex:caus3}), partgé (\ref{ex:caus4}), má tga (\ref{ex:caus5}), tga (\ref{ex:caus6}), or cunquaj tga `since' (\ref{ex:caus7}).

Content 4: \gll Cò ò la mùma dau ina sèrvla, \textbf{má} \textbf{tg}’ i è damaun dumèngja. | \gls here have.PRS.3SG DEF.F.SG mother give.PTCP.UNM INDEF.F.SG cervelat because SUBORD EXPL COP.PRS.3SG tomorrow Sunday | \glt `Here, mother provided a cervelat, because tomorrow is Sunday.'
Content 5: \gll Ùssa léjva \textbf{tg'} i è clar dé. | \gls now get_up.IMP.2SG SUBORD EXPL COP.PRS.3SG clear day | \glt `Get up now since day has already broken.'
Content 6: \gll [...] \textbf{cunquaj} \textbf{tg}' èl èra … fòrsa staus da malitèr tials tgavals, né gju da fá cun tgavals, scha … vèv’ èl … cumprau in asan, álṣò in mél, bitg in asan, in mél. | \gls … since SUBORD 3SG.M be.IMPF.3SG … maybe COP.PTCP.M.SG of army.M.SG at.DEF.M.PL horse.PL or have.PTCP.UNM to do.INF with horse.M.PL CORR … have.IMPF.3SG 3SG.M … buy.PTCP.UNM INDEF.M.SG donkey this_is INDEF.M.SG mule NEG INDEF.M.SG donkey INDEF.M.SG mule | \glt `[...] since in the army he had ... maybe been, with the horses, or had to do with horses, then ... he had ... bought a donkey, that is to say a mule, not a donkey, a mule.'

Knowledge Point: \item a correlative construction with scha ìf'' in both the protasis and the apodosis (\ref{ex:cond1} and \ref{ex:cond2}),
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Scha} té as lu mèmja bjè da raclamá a grí, \textbf{scha} matajn nus té ajnagjù ‘l Run. | \gls if 2SG have.PRS.2SG then too much ATTR complain.INF and shout.INF CORR put.PRS.1PL 1PL 2SG in_down DEF.M.SG PN | \glt `If you really have so much to complain and shout about, we will throw you down into the Run [creek].'
Content 2: \gll A da gjantá … \textbf{sch}’ ina sòra … tudèstga èra … vida majṣa, \textbf{scha} stuèvan tùt quèla- nuṣ ròmòntschas raṣdá tudèstg. | \gls and of lunch.INF … if INDEF.F.SG nun … German COP.IMPF.3SG … at_of table.F.SG CORR must.IMPF.3PL all DEM.F.SG 1PL Romansh.F.PL speak.INF German.M.SG | \glt `And during lunch … if a German … nun was … at table, all these – we, the Romansh speaking people, had to speak German.'

Knowledge Point: \item only the protasis is introduced by scha 'if' (\ref{ex:cond3}--\ref{ex:cond5}),
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Scha} ju antupás quèla gljut, \textbf{sabatès} \textbf{ju} gjù ajn ganugljaṣ a bitscháṣ als cazès. | \gls if 1SG meet.COND.1SG DEM.F.SG people REFL.throw.COND.1SG 1SG down in knee.F.PL and kiss.COND.1SG DEF.M.PL shoe.PL | \glt `If I met these people, I’d kneel down and kiss their shoes.'
Content 2: \gll [...] \textbf{scha} `l vèva bian, \textbf{vagnév}’ \textbf{ins} schòn séssúra inqual tgaussas. | \gls … if 3SG.M have.IMPF.3SG good.ADJ.UNM come.IMPF.3SG GNR indeed upon some thing.F.PL | \glt `[...] if he was in a good mood, one could get to know some things.'

Knowledge Point: \item without subordinator in the protasis but with \isi{subject inversion} and scha `if' or lura `when' in the apodosis (\ref{ex:cond6}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Tense and mood is used in the following way. \isi{Present factual conditional clauses} take the present tense in the protasis as well as in the apodosis (\ref{ex:cond1}), and \isi{past factual} {conditional clauses} are the \isi{imperfect} in both the protasis and the apodosis (\ref{ex:cond2}, \ref{ex:cond4}, \ref{ex:cond5}, and \ref{ex:cond6})
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Scha} té as lu mèmja bjè da raclamá a grí, \textbf{scha} matajn nus té ajnagjù ‘l Run. | \gls if 2SG have.PRS.2SG then too much ATTR complain.INF and shout.INF CORR put.PRS.1PL 1PL 2SG in_down DEF.M.SG PN | \glt `If you really have so much to complain and shout about, we will throw you down into the Run [creek].'
Content 2: \gll A da gjantá … \textbf{sch}’ ina sòra … tudèstga èra … vida majṣa, \textbf{scha} stuèvan tùt quèla- nuṣ ròmòntschas raṣdá tudèstg. | \gls and of lunch.INF … if INDEF.F.SG nun … German COP.IMPF.3SG … at_of table.F.SG CORR must.IMPF.3PL all DEM.F.SG 1PL Romansh.F.PL speak.INF German.M.SG | \glt `And during lunch … if a German … nun was … at table, all these – we, the Romansh speaking people, had to speak German.'
Content 4: \gll [...] \textbf{scha} `l vèva bian, \textbf{vagnév}’ \textbf{ins} schòn séssúra inqual tgaussas. | \gls … if 3SG.M have.IMPF.3SG good.ADJ.UNM come.IMPF.3SG GNR indeed upon some thing.F.PL | \glt `[...] if he was in a good mood, one could get to know some things.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Present counterfactual conditional clauses} have the \isi{direct conditional } in the protasis as well as in the apodosis (\ref{ex:cond3}), and \isi{past counterfactual conditional clauses} take the of the \isi{indirect conditional} in both the protasis and apodosis. For examples, see \sectref{sec:4.1.2.2.10}.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Scha} ju antupás quèla gljut, \textbf{sabatès} \textbf{ju} gjù ajn ganugljaṣ a bitscháṣ als cazès. | \gls if 1SG meet.COND.1SG DEM.F.SG people REFL.throw.COND.1SG 1SG down in knee.F.PL and kiss.COND.1SG DEF.M.PL shoe.PL | \glt `If I met these people, I’d kneel down and kiss their shoes.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Consecutive clauses} are introduced by tga (\ref{ex:consec1}--\ref{ex:consec3}) or by usché tga (\ref{ex:consec5}). If an \isi{adjective} triggers a \isi{consecutive clause}, the adjective is modified by schi `so' (\ref{ex:consec4}).
Content 1: \gll Èla dètgi in' jèda ina curnada li èl \textbf{tg’} \textbf{èl} \textbf{stètschi} \textbf{sél} \textbf{plaz}. | \gls 3SG.F give.PRS.SBJV.3SG one.F time DEF.F.SG push_with_horn.PTCP.F.SG DAT 3SG.M SUBORD 3SG.M stay.PRS.SBJV.3SG on.DEF.M.SG place | \glt `She [the cow] would give him a push with her horns so that he would remain on the spot.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll [...] a gl aucségnar è pròpi vagnuṣ ála lavina, ad è … staus mòrts, \textbf{usché} \textbf{tga} las stréaṣ òn … fatg vandètga cugl aucségnar da Sadrún. | \gls … and DEF.M.SG priest be.PRS.3SG really come.PTCP.M.SG into.DEF.F.SG avalanche and be.PRS.3SG … COP.PTCP.M.SG dead.M.SG so COMP DEF.F.PL witch.PL have.PRS.3PL … do.PTCP.UNM revenge.F.SG with.DEF.M.SG priest of PN | \glt `[...] and the priest really was engulfed by the avalanche and was … dead, so that the witches got their revenge on the priest of Sedrun.'
Content 4: \gll Èla è saprida ajn quaj \textbf{schi} \textbf{starmantús} \textbf{tg'} èla è curdada ajn ina rùsna nùndétga. | \gls 3SG.F be.PRS.3SG REFL.take.PTCP.F.SG in DEM.UNM so terrible.ADJ.UNM SUBORD 3SG.F be.PRS.3SG fall.PTCP.F.SG into INDEF.F.SG hole awful | \glt `She took this so seriously that she fell in an awful hole.'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Non-finite comparative clauses} are introduced by scù da, literally `how of' or `like of' (\ref{ex:comparative1}), and \isi{finite comparative clauses} are introduced by scù (\ref{ex:comparative2}) or scù tga (\ref{ex:comparative3}).
Content 1: \gll I vò fil a fil \textbf{scù} \textbf{da} \textbf{caná} in anṣégjl. | \gls EXPL go.PRS.3SG jet to jet like SUBORD stab.INF INDEF.M.SG kid | \glt `[Blood] flows like when one stabs a kid.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \isi{Concessive clauses} are introduced by schabi tga (\ref{ex:schabi1}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Schabi} \textbf{tga} lu, cun siṣ òns capév’ ins lu hald aun mèmja pauc a vèva bigja la... fòrsa da fá zatgéj. | \gls although COMP then with six year.M.PL understand.IMPF.3SG GNR then just still too little and have.IMPF.3SG NEG DEF.F.SG strength ATTR do.INF something | \glt `Although then, at the age of six, one would understand too little and wouldn’t have the ... strength to do something.'

Knowledge Point: `Instead of' only occurs in non-finite clauses in the corpus. They are introduced either by anstagl (\ref{ex:anstagl1}) or anstagl da (\ref{ex:anstagl2}).
Content 1: \gll Api \textbf{anstagl} \textbf{bájbar} \textbf{al} \textbf{vin} … èran nus lu i sé, vèvani fatg ina bòla. | \gls and instead drink.INF DEF.M.SG wine … be.IMPF.1PL 1SG then go.PTCP.M.PL up have.IMPF.3PL.3PL do.PTCP.UNM INDEF.M.SG punch | \glt `And instead of drinking the wine … we went up, they had prepared a punch.'
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In case a \isi{verb} is focused, it is moved in its \isi{infinitive} form and the finite form of the same verb is left behind in the background clause (\ref{ex:focverb1} and \ref{ex:focverb2}).
Content 1: \gll Ju a cò in bagljèt tòcan gjù Turitg, ábar \textbf{ira} \textbf{vònd} \textbf{ju} mù gjù Sumvitg. | \gls 1SG have.3SG here INDEF.M.SG ticket until down PN but go.INF go.PRS.1SG 1SG only down PN | \glt `I have here a ticket to Zurich, but I only go as far as Sumvitg.'
Content 2: \gll Na na, a \textbf{durmí} \textbf{durmévan} nus cò. | \gls no no and sleep.INF sleep.IMPF.1PL 1PL here | \glt `No, no, and as for sleeping, we would sleep here.'

Knowledge Point: In the \isi{perfect tense}, participles are moved without their \isi{auxiliary verb}, which remains in the background clause (\ref{ex:focptcp1} and \ref{ex:focptcp2}). Example (\ref{ex:focptcp3}) shows that the participle can be moved with its complements.
Content 1: \gll Ju sùn dada gjù séla fatscha, mù \textbf{fatg} \textbf{òi} nuét. | \gls 1SG be.PRS.1SG give.PTCP.F.SG down on.DEF.F.SG face but do.PTCP.UNM have.PRS.3SG.EXPL nothing | \glt `I fell down on my face but it didn'
Content 2: \gll [...] quaj è vagnú da bètòn’ ajn, a \textbf{tanju} ò laṣ aun adina. | \gls … DEM.UNM be.PRS.3SG come.PTCP.UNM COMP concrete.INF in and hold.PTCP.UNM have.PRS.3SG 3PL.F still always | \glt `[...] this has been concreted, and they still hold.'
Content 3: \gll [...] ábar \textbf{stju} \textbf{luvrá} \textbf{còrpòrálmajn} vajn nus schi fétg scù quèls. | \gls … but must.PTCP.UNM work.INF physical.ADJ.M.ADV have.PRS.1PL 1PL so much as DEM.M.PL | \glt `[...] but physically we had to work as hard as those [children].'

Knowledge Point: \isi{Infinitives} modified by a \isi{modal verb} are left-dislocated without the modal verb, which remains in the background clause (\ref{ex:focmod1}).
Content 1: \gll Als tiars vèzan al barlòt a tèman, mù \textbf{dí} \textbf{sòn} i nuét. | \gls DEF.M.PL animal.PL see.PRS.3PL DEF.M.SG sorcery and be_afraid.PRS.3PL but say.INF can.PRS.3PL 3PL nothing | \glt `The animals see the sorcery and are afraid, but they cannot say anything.'

Knowledge Point: Example (\ref{ex:focpcl1}) shows the movement of the \isi{particle} cùntar `towards' out of the particle verb prèndar ancùntar `receive' (calqued on German entgegennehmen).
Content 1: \gll Alṣò \textbf{ancùntar} prandès `l tùt ùsa? | \gls well towards take.COND.3SG 3SG all now | \glt `Well, would he receive everything now?'

Knowledge Point: If an \isi{indirect interrogative clause} is focused, it may (\ref{ex:focclause1}) or may not be resumed by a \isi{demonstrative pronoun} (\ref{ex:focclause2}). In the case of (\ref{ex:focclause1}), the \isi{demonstrative pronoun} used is gljèz.
Content 1: \gll Ins vèz’ aun tg’ èra dau vidajn pùntgas né trádals; \textbf{sch}’ \textbf{i} \textbf{sitavan} \textbf{gljèz} sau bétg. | \gls GNR see.PRS.3SG still COMP PASS.AUX.IMPF.3SG give.PTCP.UNM into chisel.F.PL or power_drill.M.PL whether 3PL blow_up.IMPF.3PL DEM.UNM know.PRS.1SG.1SG NEG | \glt `One still can see that chisels or power drills had been used; whether they would blow up I don’t know.'
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Ins vèz’ aun tg’ èra dau vidajn pùntgas né trádals; \textbf{sch}’ \textbf{i} \textbf{sitavan} \textbf{gljèz} sau bétg. | \gls GNR see.PRS.3SG still COMP PASS.AUX.IMPF.3SG give.PTCP.UNM into chisel.F.PL or power_drill.M.PL whether 3PL blow_up.IMPF.3PL DEM.UNM know.PRS.1SG.1SG NEG | \glt `One still can see that chisels or power drills had been used; whether they would blow up I don’t know.'

Knowledge Point: If the focus is on a \isi{noun}, a \isi{pronoun} referring to it must be left in the background clause (\ref{ex:focnoun1}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Contrastive focus is done by intonation; the focused constituents remain in their place according to their syntactic function (\ref{ex:foccontrnoun1} and \ref{ex:foccontrnoun2}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Gjòn} ò angulau la gaglina, bigja Maria. | \gls PN have.PRS.3SG steal.PTCP.UNM DEF.F.SG hen NEG PN | \glt `It is Gion who stole the hen, not Maria.'
Content 2: \gll Èl vut dá in cùdisch \textbf{da} \textbf{Gjòn}, bigja da Maria. | \gls 3SG.M want.PRS.3SG give.INF INDEF.M.SG book DAT PN NEG DAT PN | \glt `It is to Gion that he wants to give a book, not to Maria.'
